facts.text: Civil Appeal No. LXX of 1949 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. LXX of 1949.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment of Allahabad High Court by Verma and Yorke JJ dated 22nd April 1943.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment of the Allahabad High Court  Verma and Yorke JJ.  dated the 22nd April, 1943.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court judgment dated April 22, 1943 reversed judgment of Civil Judge of Basti dated 6th November 1939.

anchor.surface_text: which reversed on appeal those of the Civil Judge of Basti dated 6th of November 1939.

facts.text: Suit commenced by plaintiff (successor is present appellant) to recover Rs. 11,935 by enforcement of simple mortgage bond.

anchor.surface_text: The suit, out of which the appeal arises, was companymenced by the plaintiff, whose successor the present appellant is, to recover a sum of Rs. 11,935

facts.text: Mortgage deed dated 8th March 1926 executed by Raja Pateshwari Partap Narain Singh, holder of Basti Raj (impartible estate governed by primogeniture), in favour of Bhikhiram Sahu (father of original plaintiff Ramdeo).

anchor.surface_text: by enforcement of a simple mortgage bond. The mortgage deed is dated the 8th of March 1926 and was executed by Raja Pateshwari Partap Narain Singh, the then holder of Basti Raj which is an impartible estate governed by the rule of primogeniture, in favour of Bhikhiram Sahu,

facts.text: Mortgage secured loan of Rs. 5,500 on hypothecation of immovable properties of the estate, interest 9% per annum, repayable within one year.

anchor.surface_text: the father of the original plaintiff Ramdeo, to secure a loan of Rs. 5,500 advanced by the mortgagee on hypothecation of certain immovable properties appertaining to the estate of the mortgagor. The loan carried interest at the rate of 9 per cent per annum and there was a stipula- tion to pay the mortgage money within one year from the date of the bond.

facts.text: Mortgagor and mortgagee were dead when suit instituted; plaintiff Ramdeo Sahu son/heir of mortgagee; principal defendant eldest son of mortgagor who succeeded to Basti estate under primogeniture.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgagor and the mortgagee were both dead at the time when the suit was instituted, and the plaintiff in the action was Ramdeo Sahu, the son and heir of the mortgagee, while the principal defendant was the eldest son of the mortgagor who succeeded to the Basti estate under the rule of primogeniture.

facts.text: No payment made by mortgagor or successor towards mortgage dues; plaintiff claimed Rs. 5,500 principal + 9% interest to suit date.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated in the plaint that absolutely numberhing was paid by the mortgagor or his succes- sor towards the mortgage dues and the plaintiff claimed the principal amount of Rs. 5,500 together with interest at the rate of 9 per cent. per annum up to the date of the suit.

facts.text: Defendant contended document not properly attested or validly registered, could not operate as mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: The substantial companytentions raised by the defendant were of a three-fold character. In the first place, it was urged that the document sued upon was number a properly attested or valid- ly registered document and companyld number operate as a mortgage instrument in law.

facts.text: Defendant contended no consideration for Rs. 2,000 (items 3 and 4 of consideration clause).

anchor.surface_text: The second companytention raised was that there was numberconsideration in support of the transaction, at least to the extent of Rs. 2,000, which was represented by items 3 and 4 of the companysideration clause in the document.

facts.text: Defendant claimed relief under United Provinces Agriculturists Relief Act.

anchor.surface_text: The third and the last material defence related to a claim for relief under the United Provinces Agriculturists Relief Act.

facts.text: Trial Judge (Civil Judge Basti) held for defendant on Agriculturists Relief Act, negatived other pleas, preliminary decree for sale Rs.5500 + interest per Act, in installments.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge held in favour of the defendant on the last point mentioned above and negatived his other pleas. The result was that he made a preliminary decree for sale in favour of the plaintiff for recovery of the principal sum of Rs. 5,500 with interest at certain rates as are sanctioned by the U.P. Agriculturists Relief Act and agreeably to the provisions of that Act the decretal dues were directed to be paid in a number of instalments.

facts.text: Defendant appealed to Allahabad High Court, heard by Verma and York JJ.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision, the defendant took an appeal to the High Court of Allahabad which was heard by a Division Bench companysisting of Verma and York JJ.

facts.text: High Court reversed trial judge, dismissed suit: bond not attested as required, suit beyond 6 years from bond date, no money decree possible.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges reversed the judgment of the trial Judge and dismissed the plaintiffs suit on one ground only, viz., that the bond was number attested in the manner required by law and companysequently companyld number rank as a mortgage bond and as the suit was instituted beyond 6 years from the date of the bond, numbermoney decree companyld be claimed by the plaintiff.

facts.text: Mortgage deed bears signatures of executant, two attesting witnesses (Harbhajan Lal, Jawala Prasad Tewari), scribe Jawala Prasad Patwari.

anchor.surface_text: It will appear that the mortgage deed besides companytaining the signature of the executant, purports to bear the signatures of three other persons, two of whom are described as attesting wit- nesses and the third one as the scribe.

facts.text: Jawala Prasad Tewari dead when suit brought; Harbhajan Lal only surviving attesting witness, called by plaintiff to prove execution under s.68 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: Harbhajan Lal and Jawala Prasad Tewari purport to have signed the document as attesting witnesses and Jawala Prasad Patwari is the person who has signed it as the scribe. Jawala Prasad Tewari was admittedly dead when the suit was brought

facts.text: Harbhajan Lal testified he and Tewari signed as witnesses but neither signed in presence of mortgagor nor mortgagor in their presence; declared hostile.

anchor.surface_text: Harbhajan Lal stated in the witness box that he did sign the document as a witness and so did Jawala Prasad Tewari, but neither of them signed it in the presence of the mortgagor number did the mortgagor sign in their presence.

facts.text: Harbhajan Lal (cross-exam): signed at Collectorate Kutchery (Bar Library) where taken by Bhikhi Ram, Ghur Lal (Karinda), Jawala Prasad Patwari; mortgagor signature already there.

anchor.surface_text: On this statement being made, the witness was declared hostile and he was allowed to be cross examined by the plaintiffs Counsel. He was cross examined by the defendant also and in answer to the questions put to him by the defendants lawyer, he stated that he signed the deed at the Collector- ate Kutchery, meaning thereby the Bar Library, where he used to sit as a petition writer and the document was taken to him at that place by Bhikhi Ram Sahu, the mortgagee, Ghur Lal, a Karinda of the mortgagor, and Jawala Prasad Patwari, the scribe.

facts.text: Jawala Prasad Patwari (defendant witness): draft prepared at Raja's sherista under instructions from Bhikhi Ram and Ghur Lal; after fair copy/stamp, signed as scribe; taken to Kot for Raja signature; then to Collectorate for Harbhajan and Tewari signatures; registered by Jainarayan Sukul (GPA for Raja).

anchor.surface_text: The details of the defendants version relating to execution of this document were given by Jawala Prasad Patwari, who was the principal witness on the side of the defendatnt. He says that he prepared the draft at the sherista or the office of the Raja Sahib which is outside his Kot or palace. The draft was prepared under instructions from Bhikhi Ram, the mortgagee. and Ghur Lal, the Karinda of the mortgagor, both of whom were present when the draft was prepared. After the draft was fair companyied and stamped, the witness signed it as the scribe and then it was taken-by Bhikhi Ram and Ghur Lal to the Kot or palace of the Raja for his signature. After obtaining the Rajas signa- ture, Bhikhi Ram went away to his house and some time later he as well as Bhikhi Ram and Ghur Lal went to the Collector- ate Kutchery, where they took the signatures of Harbhajan Lal and Jawala Prasad Tewari. They then went to the registration office, where the document was presented for registration by Jainarayan Sukul who held a general power of attorney for the Raja.

facts.text: Plaintiff Ramdeo: document executed and attested at one sitting in Raja's Kot on 8th March 1926; terms settled beforehand; plaintiff (not father) went to palace 10-11 AM with Harbhajan Lal, Buddhu Lal, Jawala Prasad Tewari; draft by Buddhu Lal; scribed by Patwari at Raja wish; Raja signed in presence of Harbhajan and Tewari, they signed in Raja presence.

anchor.surface_text: As against this, there is a companypletely different version given by the plaintiff himself and his witness Buddhu Lal. According to the plaintiff, the document was executed and attested at one and the same sitting in the Kot or palace of the Raja the terms had been settled beforehand between Bhikhi Ram and the mortgagor and on the 8th of November 1926 the plaintiff himself, and number his father, went to the Rajas palace at about 10 or 11 A.M. in the morning to get the document executed. He was accompanied by three persons to wit Harbhajan Lal, the deed writer of his father, Buddhu Lal, an old servant of the family, and Jawala Prasad Tewari who was also well known to the plaintiff and was taken to bear witness to the deed. They found Jawala Prasad Patwari already with the Raja when they reached the Kot. The draft was prepared by Buddhu Lal at the suggestion of the Raja. It was the plaintiffs desire that the final document should be scribed by Harbhajan Lal but as the Raja wanted to oblige Jawala Prasad Patwari, who was the Patwari of Basti proper, the deed was faired out and scribed by Jawala Prasad patwari. After the Raja had put his signature on the document in the presence of Harbhajan Lal and Tewari, both the latter signed the document in the presence of the Raja.

facts.text: Plaintiff's story supported by Buddhu Lal, old family servant.

anchor.surface_text: This story of the plaintiff is supported materially and on all points by Buddhu Lal, who was an old servant of the family, though he was numberlonger in service when he deposed in companyrt.

facts.text: Trial Judge accepted plaintiff's version, rejected defendant's.

anchor.surface_text: There were thus two companyflicting versions placed before the companyrt and each side attempted to substantiate its case by verbal testimony of witnesses. The trial Judge was to decide which of the two versions was companyrect and he ac- cepted the story of the plaintiff and rejected that of the defendant.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by Mukherjea J on November 14, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: 1950. November 14. The judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by. MLKHERJEA J.

facts.text: Supreme Court held High Court wrong to reverse trial court's finding on attestation; restored trial court finding.

anchor.surface_text: Applying this principle to the present case, we do number think that the High Court was justified in reversing the finding of the trial Judge on the question of attestiation of the document.

facts.text: Buddhu Lal named as witness in registered receipt Ex.10 for Rs.500 paid by Bhikhi Ram under mortgage terms.

anchor.surface_text: That he was trusted in business matters is clear from the fact that his name appears as a witness in the registered receipt  Ex. 10  given by Sheo Balak Ram, to whom a sum of Rs. 500 was paid by Bhikhi Ram under the terms of the dis- puted mortgage deed.

anchor.surface_text: The question for our consideration is undoubtedly one of fact, the decision of which depends upon the appreciation of the oral evidence adduced in the case. In such cases, the appellate court has got to bear in mind that it has not the advantage which the trial Judge had in having the witnesses before him and of observing the manner in which they deposed in court. This certainly does not mean that when an appeal lies on facts, the appellate court is not competent to reverse a finding of fact arrived at by the trial Judge. The rule is--and it is nothing more than a rule of practice --that when there is conflict of oral evidence of the parties on any matter in issue and the decision hinges upon the credibility of the witnesses, then unless there is some special feature about the evidence of a particular witness which has escaped the trial Judges notice or there is a sufficient balance of improbability to displace his opinion as to where the credibility lies, the appellate court should not interfere with the finding of the trial Judge on a question of fact . The gist of the numerous decisions on this subject was clearly summed up by Viscount Simon in Watt v. Thomas

concepts.interpretation: Appellate court should not reverse trial court's finding on credibility unless special feature or inherent improbability; trial judge's view entitled to great weight as saw witnesses; applied to hold High Court erred in reversing on attestation

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: t of his companyclusion that Harbhajan Lal signed the document at the place of its execution and number at the Collectorate Kutchery as alleged by him

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court in dealing with the appeal do observe, at the beginning of their discussions, that on a question of fact the appellate court should be slow to differ from the conclusions arrived at by the trial Judge who had seen and heard the witnesses but in their opinion, this rule did not apply to the present case as the trial Judge here did not base his conclusions on the impressions created in his mind by the witnesses who deposed before him.

arguments.claim: Plaintiff's story improbable: not probable plaintiff (not father) present at Raja's palace for execution as against customs and Raja's high position

anchor.surface_text: In the opinion of the High Court the story narrated by the plaintiff and his servant is untrue, and the main reason given is that it is not at all probable that the plaintiff and not his father Bhikhi Ram was present at the palace of the Raja when the document was executed. The mortgagor, it is said, was an influential person in the locality occupying a very high social position and it would be indecorous and against Indian customs for a man like Bhikhi Ram not to be personally present

arguments.claim: Trial judge's finding value not detracted if not expressly based on demeanour impressions

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was wrong in thinking that it would detract from the value to be attached to a trial Judges finding of fact if the Judge does not expressly base his conclusion upon the impressions he gathers from the demeanour of witnesses.

arguments.claim: Plaintiff's presence probable: adult son represented father; terms settled beforehand; executed at borrower's palace

anchor.surface_text: if as the plaintiff says, the terms were already settled between Bhikhi Ram and the Raja and the only thing left was to embody the agreed terms in writing, we fail to see why it was absolutely necessary for Bhikhi Ram to wait upon the mortgagor personally and why his adult son, who was sufficiently old and experienced in business affairs, could not represent him in the transaction.

arguments.claim: Harbhajan Lal, experienced deed writer, knew attestation requirements and signed properly at execution

anchor.surface_text: we do agree with the trial Judge in holding that Harbhajan Lal must have signed the document at the time when it was executed and not afterwards and it is really inconceivable that an old-and experienced deed writer like him did not know the requirements of proper attestation.

arguments.claim: Harbhajan Lal ordinarily scribed plaintiff's father's deeds; natural to take him; Patwari scribed due to Raja's wish

anchor.surface_text: so far as the plaintiffs father was concerned, there is no doubt whatsoever that Harbhajan Lal was the scribe ordinarily employed to do his work. In this case also if Jawala Prasad Patwari had not been present on the spot, the plaintiff would certainly have the document scribed by Harbhajan Lal... out of deference to the wishes of the Raja that the plaintiff consented to the document being scribed by Jawala Prasad Patwari.

arguments.claim: Buddhu Lal trusted family servant in business; natural to accompany
Jawala Prasad Patwari under defendant's control, not trustworthy; Harbhajan condemned by own statement

anchor.surface_text: Jawala Prasad Patwari is apparently a man under the control of the defendant and cannot be trusted... Harbhajan Lal stands condemned by his own statement in court.

holdings.text: The rule is that when there is conflict of oral evidence of the parties on any matter in issue and the decision hinges upon the credibility of the witnesses, then unless there is some special feature about the evidence of a particular witness which has escaped the trial Judge's notice or there is a sufficient balance of improbability to displace his opinion as to where the credibility lies, the appellate court should not interfere with the finding of the trial Judge on a question of fact.

anchor.surface_text: The rule is--and it is nothing more than a rule of practice --that when there is conflict of oral evidence of the parties on any matter in issue and the decision hinges upon the credibility of the witnesses, then unless there is some special feature about the evidence of a par- ticular witness which has escaped the trial Judges notice or there is a sufficient balance of improbability to dis- place his opinion as to where the credibility lies, the appellate court should not interfere with the finding of the trial Judge on a question of fact .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Summarizes rule of practice from Watt v. Thomas and Judicial Committee cases; appellate court lacks advantage of seeing witnesses; trial judge's credibility assessment entitled to great weight.

holdings.text: The High Court was wrong in thinking that it would detract from the value to be attached to a trial Judge's finding of fact if the Judge does not expressly base his conclusion upon the impressions he gathers from the demeanour of witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was wrong in thinking that it would detract from the value to be attached to a trial Judges finding of fact if the Judge does not expressly base his conclusion upon the impressions he gathers from the demeanour of witnesses .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial judge's advantage in observing witnesses persists even if not expressly stated; cites Netherlandsche Handel Maatschappij v. R.M.A.P. Chettiar.

holdings.text: Applying this principle to the present case, we do not think that the High Court was justified in reversing the finding of the trial Judge on the question of attestation of the document.

anchor.surface_text: Applying this principle to the present case, we do number think that the High Court was justified in reversing the finding of the trial Judge on the question of attestiation of the document.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence as whole reasonably supports trial finding; no special feature or improbability displacing it; High Court reversed on inadequate grounds.

holdings.text: We have no hesitation in holding that Harbhajan Lal knew perfectly well what attestation means in law and he did sign the document as an attesting witness at the Raja's Kot after the document was executed.

anchor.surface_text: Whatever that may be, we have numberhesitation in holding that Harbhajan Lal knew perfectly well what attestation means in law and he did sign the document as an attesting witness at the Rajas Kot after the document was executed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harbhajan Lal experienced deed writer; inconceivable he attested improperly; his evidence self-condemnatory; supports trial finding under s.68 Evidence Act.

holdings.text: Our conclusion is that the finding of the trial Judge on the question of attestation is perfectly consistent with the circumstances and probabilities of the case... The evidence on the record taken as a whole fully supports the finding, and in our opinion the High Court has reversed it on totally inadequate grounds.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff's version probable (son representing father, trusted witnesses present); defendant's witnesses unreliable; overall evidence justifies attestation finding.

anchor.surface_text: The rule is--and it is nothing more than a rule of practice --that when there is conflict of oral evidence of the parties on any matter in issue and the decision hinges upon the credibility of the witnesses, then unless there is some special feature about the evidence of a par- ticular witness which has escaped the trial Judges notice or there is a sufficient balance of improbability to dis- place his opinion as to where the credibility lies, the appellate court should not interfere with the finding of the trial Judge on a question of fact .
Applying this principle to the present case, we do number think that the High Court was justified in reversing the finding of the trial Judge on the question of attestation of the document.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was wrong in thinking that it would detract from the value to be attached to a trial Judges finding of fact if the Judge does not expressly base his conclusion upon the impressions he gathers from the demeanour of witnesses .
Applying this principle to the present case, we do number think that the High Court was justified in reversing the finding of the trial Judge on the question of attestation of the document.
